newsitem.title: PANAMA: Panama sends police to troubled Colombian border.
newsitem.headline: Panama sends police to troubled Colombian border.

text.p: Panama said on Monday it was sending a 1,000-strong police force to beef up security at its troubled border zone following reports of Colombian paramilitary groups crossing in search of guerrillas.
"Panama does not have the personnel to guard the border," National Police spokesman Jose Zamora told Reuters.
The 1,000-man contingent will leave for the dense Darien jungle region Thursday to join the roughly 300 police already stationed along the 190-mile (300 km) frontier, Zamora said.
"This is a zone with many bandits and many criminals, it's an open zone and that is why we're acting now," he said.
Non-governmental organisations in the area warned recently that incursions by Colombian paramilitary and rebel groups were growing more frequent.

"We note with deep concern that the armed conflict in Colombia is extending and each time entering more into Panama's territory," Romulo Emiliani, Roman Catholic bishop of the Darien region, said in a statement.
Emiliani said a column of more than 40 fighters from Colombia's right-wing paramilitary Peasant Defence Group of Cordoba and Uraba (ACCU) briefly seized the border village Yape on June 23.
"Behind them, in the mountain, there was a contingent, awaiting their orders. They were checking up on the village, looking for guerrillas," Emiliani said.
Zamora said the frontier zone was sparsely manned and very difficult to control. He said the police stationed there carried mainly handguns with just a few M-16 machine guns.
Panama's constitution prevents the country from having a military. Instead it has a police force of about 17,000 under civilian control.
